section.title: Download on Demand Projects (DoD)
section.para:
In a DoD project external software repositories can be configured which should be used for dependency resolution and where package can be downloaded at the build time. A DoD project has some main advantages in comparison to binary import projects:
less disk usage as only really required packages are download
automatic package updates when new upstream releases are availible
simple to configure in project meta without need of shell access to repo servers
The bs_dodup daemon periodically checks for new meta data in remote repositories.
This daemon can be enabled for startup with the command
systemctl enable obsdodup.service
and can be started with
systemctl start obsdodup.service
All cached data (meta data and packages will be stored in $BSConfig::bsdir/dods (default for $BSConfig::bsdir is "/srv/obs")

section.title: RPM sources (rpmmd)
section.para: The master entry defines the url to the original source of the repository and be defined as https and a given ssl fingerprint, so we can check if repo data is valid. The download url can be a mirror as we validate package checksums found in repo data.

para.screen:
<project name="Fedora:Rawhide">
...
<repository name="standard"> <download arch="x86_64" url="http://mirror.example.org/fedora/rawhide/x86_64/os" repotype="rpmmd"> <master url="https://master.example.org/whereever/fedora/rawhide/x86_64/os" sslfingerprint="sha256:0a64..0303"/> </download> <download arch="i586" url="http://mirror.example.org/fedora/rawhide/i386/os" repotype="rpmmd"> <master url="https://master.example.org/whereever/fedora/rawhide/i386/os" sslfingerprint="sha256:0a64..0303"/> </download> <arch>x86_64</arch> <arch>i586</arch> </repository> </project>

section.para:
You can easily query the ssl fingerprint of a remote server by calling the following command:
openssl s_client -connect <host>:<port> < /dev/null 2>/dev/null | openssl x509 -fingerprint -noout -in /dev/stdin

para.screen:
<project name="Debian:8">
...
<repository name="update"> <download arch="x86_64" url="http://ftp.de.debian.org/debian/jessie-updates/main" repotype="deb"/> <download arch="i586" url="http://ftp.de.debian.org/debian/jessie-updates/main" repotype="deb"/> <path project="Debian:7" repository="ga"/> <arch>x86_64</arch> <arch>i586</arch> </repository> <repository name="ga"> <download arch="x86_64" url="http://ftp.de.debian.org/debian/jessie/main" repotype="deb"/> <download arch="i586" url="http://ftp.de.debian.org/debian/jessie/main" repotype="deb"/> <arch>x86_64</arch> <arch>i586</arch> </repository> </project>

section.title: Arch Sources
section.para:
In Arch repositories we have no chance to validate packages. Please be aware that this might be insecure.
<project name="Arch:Core">
...
<repository name="standard"> <download arch="x86_64" url="http://ftp5.gwdg.de/pub/linux/archlinux/core/os/x86_64" repotype="arch"/> <download arch="i586" url="http://ftp5.gwdg.de/pub/linux/archlinux/core/os/i686" repotype="arch"/> <arch>x86_64</arch> <arch>i586</arch> </repository> </project>
